summary: This document is an email chain regarding the case US v. Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). It forwards a memo endorsement signed by Judge Nathan concerning an ex parte sealed letter from the Government, filed under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(d)(1). The communication is between court staff and a federal prosecutor.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge Nathan signed the memo endorsement regarding the ex parte sealed letter in the US v. Maxwell case.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: Law Clerk to Judge Nathan who sent the memo endorsement to the recipients and requested confirmation of receipt.

connections.description: Nathan serves as the Law Clerk to Judge Alison J. Nathan, as indicated in the email signature.

events.title: Memo Endorsement on Ex Parte Sealed Letter
events.description: Judge Nathan signed a memo endorsement regarding an ex parte sealed letter from the Government in the US v. Maxwell case, which is to remain temporarily under seal.

events.title: Government's Ex Parte Sealed Letter Submission
events.description: The Government submitted a letter pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(d)(1) to Judge Nathan, requesting it be filed ex parte and under seal.

keyFacts: The document pertains to the criminal case US v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN).
Judge Alison J. Nathan signed a memo endorsement regarding an ex parte sealed letter from the Government.
The Government's letter was submitted under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(d)(1) and requested to be filed ex parte and under seal.
The memo endorsement was to remain temporarily under seal as of September 15, 2020.
The correspondence involves the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, located at 1 St. Andrew's Plaza.
